title: The Living SEB app
text: This app allows using the Living SEB Project materials app link to navigate and meta-analyse evidence from all cross-sectional SEB studies.

title: Character strengths meta-analysis
text:
This app (app link) allows exploring the results of our meta-analysis (Casali & Feraco, 2025) testing the associations between character strengths and well-being.
More information on the meta-analysis here: https://doi.org/10.1177/08902070251366765

title: Tommaso Feraco
text:
tommaso.feraco@unipd.it
I am a researcher at the Department of General Psychology, University of Padova, Italy.
My research interests include personality, intelligence, SEB skills, geographical psychology, meta-research, measurement, and research methods.

title: Courses and Open Teaching materials
text:
This page collects the main courses and open materials I make publicly available. Whenever possible, slides, exercises, and code are freely accessible so that students, teachers, and researchers can reuse or adapt them.




Structural Equation Modeling 



Course website: https://enricotoffalini.github.io/SEM-course/
Short description
This course introduces the foundations of Structural Equation Modeling (SEM), covering latent variables, CFA, path analysis, and measurement invariance. You will learn how to specify, estimate, and test SEM models in R using the lavaan package, as well as perform power analysis through simulation.
What you can find here

üìë Slides and lecture notes

Conceptual slides introducing R as a language for data science

Step-by-step examples to reproduce directly in R / RStudio

üß™ Hands-on exercises

Guided exercises for getting familiar with lavaan syntax

Small data sets used in class, ready to be reused in other courses or self-study


Who this is useful for

PhD students and early-career researchers who need a compact, applied introduction to SEM

Teachers who want ready-made R exercises and examples and slides to integrate in their own courses






Psicologia della Personalit√† e delle Differenze Individuali 



Sito del corso e materiali aperti: https://feracotommaso.github.io/Personality-and-individual-differences/
Corso triennale introduttivo sulla psicologia della personalit√† e sulle differenze individuali. Il corso affronta:

la definizione di personalit√†

i maggiori modelli di personalit√†

i principali strumenti di misura della personalit√†

varie tipologie e aree di ricerca delle differenze individuali

Materiali disponibili

üìë Dispense e approfondimenti
Tutte le dispense usate in aggiunta ai testi di studio sono state scritte e rese disponibili online sulla pagina principale del corso. Questi materiali possono essere riutilizzati (con citazione) per attivit√† didattiche, divulgative o di autoformazione.
üìë Risultati delle esercitazioni
Durante il corso, raccogliamo e analizziamo dati di personalit√†. Le slide con i risultati vengono pubblicate sul sito per consultazione.

A chi pu√≤ essere utile

Persone curiose di capire meglio come e perch√® le persone sono diverse una dall‚Äôaltra e quali modelli spiegano meglio tali differenze;
Studentesse e studenti di psicologia, neuroscienze, materie umanistiche;
Docenti che cercano materiali pronti all‚Äôuso per lezioni sui temi di personalit√† e differenze individuali.






‚úÖ You are welcome to link to these course pages, embed specific exercises in your own syllabi, or recommend them to students.

‚úÖ Slides and code examples are generally fine to reuse for non-commercial teaching, ideally with a short acknowledgement (but for the MOOC on Federica Web Learning, please refer to the Federica license before copying any part!).

‚ùì If you plan a more extensive reuse (for example, translating large parts of material, or integrating them into a paid course), it‚Äôs generally fine, but please get in touch first.





If you are interested in using or adapting these materials for your course, or if you have suggestions for improvements: tommaso.feraco@unipd.it
I am always happy to see these resources reused, remixed, and improved, especially when they help promote better methods and critical thinking in psychological science.
